natural problem: When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$
natural solution: Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]

usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));

draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);

[/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v = (-5, 1)"
and h1 : "v = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "p = projection v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v = (-5, 1)"
and h1 : "v = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "p = projection v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two vectors $v = (-5, 1)$ and $v = (2, 3)$, find the projection of the first vector onto the second. The final answer is $(-34/53, 119/53)$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
and v1 :: "real*real" 
and v2 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v1 = (-5, 1)"
and h1 : "v2 = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "p = (projection v v1)"
and h3 : "p = (projection v v2)"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));

 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
and v1 :: "real*real" 
and v2 :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v1 = (-5, 1)"
and h1 : "v2 = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "p = (projection v v1)"
and h3 : "p = (projection v v2)"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two vectors v1 = (-5, 1) and v2 = (2, 3), find the projection of vector v onto v1 and v2 if they are the same. The final answer is (-34/53, 119/53).

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2" and a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a *\<^sub>R v = vector [-5, 1]"
and h1 : "b *\<^sub>R v = vector [2, 3]"
shows  "p = vector [-34 / 53, 119 / 53]"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2" and a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a *\<^sub>R v = vector [-5, 1]"
and h1 : "b *\<^sub>R v = vector [2, 3]"
shows  "p = vector [-34 / 53, 119 / 53]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Let $v$ be a vector in 2-dimensional real space. If $-5v_1 + v_2 = a$ and $2v_1 + 3v_2 = b$, find the vector $p$ such that $p = \left[-\frac{34}{53}, \frac{119}{53}\right]$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
and a b :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "a = (-5,1)"
and h1 : "b = (2,3)"
and h2 : "p = (a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "p = (b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
and a b :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "a = (-5,1)"
and h1 : "b = (2,3)"
and h2 : "p = (a \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h3 : "p = (b \<bullet> v / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given two points $a = (-5, 1)$ and $b = (2, 3)$, and the vector $v$, find the projection of $a$ and $b$ onto $v$. If the projections of both $a$ and $b$ onto $v$ are the same, calculate the coordinates of the point $p$ which is the projection. The final coordinates of point $p$ are $(-34/53, 119/53)$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "projection (-5,1) v = projection (2,3) v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "projection (-5,1) v = projection (2,3) v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the point $p$ at which the projections of the vector $v$ onto the points $(-5,1)$ and $(2,3)$ are equal. The final answer is $p = \left(-\frac{34}{53}, \frac{119}{53}\right)$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p v :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "p = ((-5 * fst v + 1 * snd v) / (fst v * fst v + snd v * snd v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h1 : "p = ((2 * fst v + 3 * snd v) / (fst v * fst v + snd v * snd v)) *\<^sub>R v"
shows  "p = (-34 / 53, 119 / 53)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p v :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "p = ((-5 * fst v + 1 * snd v) / (fst v * fst v + snd v * snd v)) *\<^sub>R v"
and h1 : "p = ((2 * fst v + 3 * snd v) / (fst v * fst v + snd v * snd v)) *\<^sub>R v"
shows  "p = (-34 / 53, 119 / 53)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find a point p on the vector v that satisfies the following two conditions: The projection of p onto v equals to the quantity of $-5$ times the x-coordinate of v plus the y-coordinate of v, all divided by the magnitude of v squared, times v; and the projection of p onto v equals to the quantity of $2$ times the x-coordinate of v plus $3$ times the y-coordinate of v, all divided by the magnitude of v squared, times v. The final answer is $p = (-\frac{34}{53}, \frac{119}{53})$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v = (-5, 1)"
and h1 : "v = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "p = projection v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "v = (-5, 1)"
and h1 : "v = (2, 3)"
and h2 : "p = projection v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a vector $v = (-5, 1)$ and another vector $v = (2, 3)$, find the projection of the first vector onto the second vector. The final answer is $p = (-34/53, 119/53)$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. \<exists> k. x - k *\<^sub>R y = p"
and h1 : "\<forall> v. h0 (-5,1) v"
and h2 : "\<forall> v. h0 (2,3) v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. \<exists> k. x - k *\<^sub>R y = p"
and h1 : "\<forall> v. h0 (-5,1) v"
and h2 : "\<forall> v. h0 (2,3) v"
shows  "p = (-34/53, 119/53)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given that for any pair of real numbers x and y, there exists a real number k such that x - ky = p, and this holds for vectors v = (-5,1) and v = (2,3), find the value of p. The final answer is p = (-34/53, 119/53).

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real*real" and p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "(-5, 1) \<bullet> v = p \<bullet> v"
and h1 : "(2, 3) \<bullet> v = p \<bullet> v"
shows  "p = (-34 / 53, 119 / 53)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real*real" and p :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "(-5, 1) \<bullet> v = p \<bullet> v"
and h1 : "(2, 3) \<bullet> v = p \<bullet> v"
shows  "p = (-34 / 53, 119 / 53)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given two vectors, $v$ and $p$, in a 2D plane. If the dot product of $v$ with $(-5, 1)$ is equal to the dot product of $p$ and $v$, and the dot product of $v$ with $(2, 3)$ is also equal to the dot product of $p$ and $v$, find the vector $p$. The final answer is $(-\frac{34}{53}, \frac{119}{53})$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [a, b]"
and h1 : "p = vector [c, d]"
and h2 : "vector_projection (vector [-5, 1]) v = p"
and h3 : "vector_projection (vector [2, 3]) v = p"
shows  "p = vector [-34/53, 119/53]"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 When the vectors $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$ are both projected onto the same vector $\mathbf{v},$ the result is $\mathbf{p}$ in both cases.  Find $\mathbf{p}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that the vector $\mathbf{p}$ must lie on the line passing through $\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}.$  This line can be parameterized by \[\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) = \begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + t \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][asy]
 usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); pair A, B, O, P; A = (-5,1); B = (2,3); O = (0,0); P = (O + reflect(A,B)*(O))/2; draw((-6,0)--(3,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,4)); draw(O--A,Arrow(6)); draw(O--B,Arrow(6));
 draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(interp(A,B,-0.1)--interp(A,B,1.1),dashed); label("$\begin{pmatrix} -5 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$", A, N); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$", B, N); label("$\mathbf{p}$", P, N);
 [/asy] The vector $\mathbf{p}$ itself will be orthogonal to the direction vector $\begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ so \[\begin{pmatrix} 7t - 5 \\ 2t + 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 7 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = 0.\]Hence, $(7t - 5)(7) + (2t + 1)(2) = 0.$  Solving, we find $t = \frac{33}{53}.$  Hence, $\mathbf{p} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -34/53 \\ 119/53 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v p :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [a, b]"
and h1 : "p = vector [c, d]"
and h2 : "vector_projection (vector [-5, 1]) v = p"
and h3 : "vector_projection (vector [2, 3]) v = p"
shows  "p = vector [-34/53, 119/53]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given two vectors, $v$ and $p$ in 2-dimensional space where $v$ is a vector with components $a$ and $b$, and $p$ is a vector with components $c$ and $d$. If $p$ is the projection of $v$ onto the vectors $[-5, 1]$ and $[2, 3]$, find the components of vector $p$. The answer is $p = [-\frac{34}{53}, \frac{119}{53}]$.
